conclusion: Understanding the problem involves a p-V diagram for an ideal gas transitioning from state A to B to C, with known temperature at state A.
The p-V diagram has pressure on the y-axis and volume on the x-axis, with points A, B, and C connected in order.
At point A: Pressure is 3 x 10^5 Pa, Volume is 2 x 10^-3 m³.
At point B: Pressure is 2 x 10^5 Pa, Volume is 2 x 10^-3 m³.
At point C: Pressure is 2 x 10^5 Pa, Volume is 3 x 10^-3 m³.
Temperature at state A is 27 °C, need to find temperature at state B using ideal gas law.
Ideal gas law: pv = nRT, where p is pressure, v is volume, n is moles, R is gas constant, T is temperature.
Convert temperature at state A from Celsius to Kelvin: T_A = 300.15 K.
Using ideal gas law at state A: p_A v_A = n R T_A.
Using ideal gas law at state B: p_B v_B = n R T_B.
Set up ratio: (p_B v_B) / (p_A v_A) = T_B / T_A.
Plug in known values and simplify: (2/3) = T_B / 300.15.
Convert T_B back to Celsius: t_B = -73.05 °C.
Realize the temperature seems too low and decide to double-check calculations.
Re-evaluate ratio: (p_B v_B) / (p_A v_A) = T_B / T_A.
